title: Polymer Chemistry in Plastics
scenario: A materials scientist must choose between polyethylene (PE) and polylactic acid (PLA) for a packaging application, considering mechanical properties, production, and biodegradability.
content:
Polyethylene is formed by addition polymerisation of ethylene (CH₂=CH₂ → [−CH₂−CH₂−]ₙ) using Ziegler-Natta catalysts. It is non-polar, hydrophobic, and highly resistant to degradation — a key environmental problem. HDPE (high-density PE) has straight chains and high tensile strength; LDPE has branched chains and is more flexible.

PLA is a biodegradable polyester made from lactic acid (from corn starch fermentation). The ester linkages (−COO−) can be hydrolysed by bacteria and water, breaking PLA into CO₂ and H₂O. The trade-off: PLA costs more and has lower heat resistance than PE.
guided_questions: Write the addition polymerisation reaction for ethylene (with n monomers).
Why is polyethylene resistant to degradation? What chemical property makes PLA biodegradable?
Compare the intermolecular forces in HDPE vs LDPE and predict which has a higher melting point.
what_you_learned: Polymer chemistry illustrates addition and condensation polymerisation, structure-property relationships, intermolecular forces, and the chemistry of biodegradation — all critical for sustainable materials design.
